title: Don't Stop Believin'
composer: Steve Perry, Neal Schon & Jonathan Cain

musicalLanguage.description: One of the most recognizable piano intros in rock history. Jonathan Cain's opening riff is a simple broken chord pattern cycling through E-B-C#m-A. This beginner arrangement captures the essence of the riff with a simplified right-hand pattern and basic left-hand bass notes.
musicalLanguage.structure: Intro-Verse riff (8 bars) — E-B-C#m-A repeated twice
keyMoments: Bars 1-2: E to B — the bright, optimistic opening that everyone knows
Bars 3-4: C#m to A — the minor chord adds depth, then A brings it back to warmth
Bars 5-8: Same progression repeated — by the second time, your hands know the way
teachingGoals: Playing in E major — four sharps (F#, C#, G#, D#)
Simple broken chord patterns in the right hand
styleTips: Keep the rhythm steady and bright — this is feel-good arena rock
The right hand pattern should be light and bouncy, not heavy
Think of a crowd singing along — this music is meant to uplift

measures.rightHand: E4:e G#4:e B4:e E5:e B4:e G#4:e E4:e G#4:e
measures.teachingNote: E major broken chord — the iconic opening riff. Bright and hopeful.

measures.rightHand: F#4:e B4:e D#5:e B4:e F#4:e B4:e D#5:e B4:e
measures.teachingNote: B major — same pattern transposed. The D# gives the major third its brightness.

measures.rightHand: E4:e G#4:e C#5:e G#4:e E4:e G#4:e C#5:e G#4:e
measures.teachingNote: C# minor — the only minor chord. Notice G# stays while B changes to C#5. Subtle shift.

measures.rightHand: E4:e A4:e C#5:e A4:e E4:e A4:e C#5:e A4:e
measures.teachingNote: A major — warm and grounding. The IV chord feels like coming home before the loop.

measures.rightHand: E4:e G#4:e B4:e E5:e B4:e G#4:e E4:e G#4:e
measures.teachingNote: E major again — second time through. Your fingers should be finding the patterns now.

measures.rightHand: F#4:e B4:e D#5:e B4:e F#4:e B4:e D#5:e B4:e
measures.teachingNote: B major — same as bar 2. Repetition builds confidence and groove.

measures.rightHand: E4:e G#4:e C#5:e G#4:e E4:e G#4:e C#5:e G#4:e
measures.teachingNote: C# minor — the bittersweet moment before the final resolution.
A to E — the phrase closes on the tonic. You just played one of rock's greatest piano parts.
